title: Analysis of 'Neural computation of log likelihood in control of saccadic eye movements'
text: digitised version raw data study included package LATERmodel::carpenter_williams_1995 variable. variable dataframe rows corresponding trials columns named participant, condition, time. recommended format raw data used LATERmodel package. participant condition columns specify identifiers participant condition, respectively, time column specifies measured response time (milliseconds). rows corresponding particular unique combination participant condition referred dataset within package. can look first rows, using head function, see structure dataframe: LATERmodel::carpenter_williams_1995 contains trials participants b interested participant b , extract trials participant b variable using subset function:
code: head(LATERmodel::carpenter_williams_1995) raw_data <- subset(x = LATERmodel::carpenter_williams_1995, participant == "b")

title: Analysis of 'Neural computation of log likelihood in control of saccadic eye movements'
text: data analysis functions within LATERmodel package require raw data first undergo pre-processing using LATERmodel::prepare_data function. pass raw_data variable argument raw_data parameter LATERmodel::prepare_data perform pre-processing: Note raw data response times units milliseconds, used time_unit parameter LATERmodel::prepare_data specify units (see documentation LATERmodel::prepare_data details). can view first rows inspect output pre-processing: shown , data now columns name (formed combination participant condition columns raw data), promptness (inverse time column, now specified seconds), e_cdf (evaluated empirical cumulative distribution function dataset). make condition names match used Carpenter Williams (1995), can recode :
code: data <- LATERmodel::prepare_data(raw_data = raw_data) head(data) #> # A tibble: 6 × 4 #> # Groups:   name [1] #>    time name  promptness e_cdf #>   <dbl> <fct>      <dbl> <dbl> #> 1  0.15 b_p05       6.67 0.998 #> 2  0.17 b_p05       5.88 0.996 #> 3  0.19 b_p05       5.26 0.992 #> 4  0.19 b_p05       5.26 0.992 #> 5  0.2  b_p05       5    0.977 #> 6  0.2  b_p05       5    0.977 # make the names match C&W data$name <- dplyr::recode_factor(   .x = data$name,   b_p05 = "5%",   b_p10 = "10%",   b_p25 = "25%",   b_p50 = "50%",   b_p75 = "75%",   b_p90 = "90%",   b_p95 = "95%" )

title: Analysis of 'Neural computation of log likelihood in control of saccadic eye movements'
text: can use LATERmodel::reciprobit_plot function visualise observed data ‘reciprobit’ space:  produces plot empirical cumulative distribution function values datasets data shown individual points, points different datasets shown different colours (colours can set user-specified values using LATERmodel::prepare_data function referred earlier, desired). lower horizontal axis shows response time latency, seconds, increasing positively non-linearly right. upper horizontal axis shows reciprocal response time latency, promptness, decreasing linearly. left vertical axis shows cumulative probability non-linear (probit) spacing, right vertical axis shows linear spacing (z-scores).
code: LATERmodel::reciprobit_plot(plot_data = data)

title: Analysis of 'Neural computation of log likelihood in control of saccadic eye movements'
text: first consider can fit LATER model observations single dataset: 95% condition. First, data contains trials conditions participant b, extract relevant data: can use LATERmodel::fit_data function perform fitting. fitting single dataset, important decision make whether model include early component, corresponding fast responses. inclusion model component controlled with_early_component parameter LATERmodel::fit_data, defaults FALSE. , fit data including early component. Note additional decision make fitting criterion used quantify goodness fit. criterion specifies method obtaining value fitting algorithm seeks optimise exploring model’s parameter space. criterion supplied LATERmodel::fit_data via fit_criterion parameter. specific criterion specified, default LATERmodel optimise likelihood (fit criterion = "likelihood"). alternative optimise Kolmogorov-Smirnov statistic, can specified via fit_criterion = "ks". fitting data, fit_data function attempts find set start points model parameters (based summaries observed raw data) likely close final values obtained parameter optimisation. provide robustness specific start points used, function defaults performing additional 7 fits (parallel), random amount jitter added start points - function returns fit best (lowest fit criterion value). settings jittering can set passing jitter_settings argument fit_data. example, jittering can disabled passing jitter_settings = list(n = 0). Importantly, random jitters can made reproducible passing ‘seed’ (positive integer), jitter_settings = list(seed = 51221). document, use seeds produce reproducible values. returned variable, named fit_p95, contains information fitting parameters fitting result. best-fitting parameter values can accessed named_fit_params variable: able interpret model parameters, briefly consider components LATER model (see Carpenter Noorani (2023) detailed information LATER model). key assumption LATER model inverse response time (promptness) can modeled Normal distribution. distribution can either parameterised via location (\(\mu\)) scale (\(\sigma\)) parameters via intercept (\(k\)) scale (\(\sigma\)) parameters; refer latter parameterisation ‘intercept form’ (named \(k\) parameter describes point z-score space response time latency approaches infinity), need two different parameterisations become clearer “Multiple datasets fitted together” section . ambiguity around whether Normal distribution parameterised \(\left(\mu, \sigma\right)\) \(\left(k, \sigma\right)\), refer Normal distribution parameters \(\left(, \sigma\right)\) allow \(\) take value either μ k depending desired parameterisation. best-fitting values \(\) \(\sigma\) dataset shown table (\(s\), also present table, simply \(1 / \sigma\)). table also shows best-fitting \(\mu\) value, identical value reported \(\) - indicates Normal distribution fit parameterisation \(= \mu\) (default LATERmodel::fit_data). location intercept parameters related via \(\mu = k \sigma\) \(k = \mu / \sigma\), also report value \(k\) table . mentioned previously, LATER model can also include early component addition primary component described . early component also assumed Normally distributed promptness space, fixed value \(\mu\) (\(k\)) zero. scale parameter component labelled \(\sigma_e\). According LATER model, early primary components compete produce response time given trial - whichever highest promptness (lowest response time) responsible producing response time. early component location parameter set low value (0) promptness space, likely generate lower value primary component. However, relatively high value \(\sigma_e\), capacity occasionally produce high values promptness; , able describe unusually fast response times. best-fitting value \(\sigma_e\) also reported table . visually assess reasonableness fitted parameters, can visualise fit passing variable containing parameters LATERmodel::reciprobit_plot function:
code: data_p95 <- subset(x = data, name == "95%") fit_p95 <- LATERmodel::fit_data(   data = data_p95,   with_early_component = TRUE,   jitter_settings = list(seed = 341971432) ) fit_p95$named_fit_params LATERmodel::reciprobit_plot(   plot_data = data_p95,   fit_params = fit_p95$named_fit_params )

title: Analysis of 'Neural computation of log likelihood in control of saccadic eye movements'
text: want fit multiple datasets consider dataset separately fitting, can use LATERmodel::individual_later_fit helper function. , use fit conditions example data: function returns dataframe contains columns entries named_fit_params component fit information (along additional columns relating fit): can plot result, .  Note , contrast figure Carpenter Williams (1995) shown beginning document, plots show fits complete model rather attempting isolate early primary components. following explanation Carpenter Noorani (2023), p. 26, different plotting approaches, approach package corresponds ‘alternative’ describe (‘main’ ‘maverick’ components correspond ‘primary’ ‘early’ components): “important point although clarity can often helpful plot asymptotes – effect, two separate components corresponding main maverick components – data points expected go : alternative plot combined theoretical distribution resulting components together”
code: individual_named_fit_params <- LATERmodel::individual_later_fit(   df = data,   with_early_component = TRUE,   jitter_settings = list(seed = 561866110) ) individual_named_fit_params LATERmodel::reciprobit_plot(   plot_data = data,   fit_params = individual_named_fit_params )

title: Analysis of 'Neural computation of log likelihood in control of saccadic eye movements'
text: might interested situations multiple datasets LATER model parameter value. refer scenario sharing model parameters. Note can take long time command fit complex LATER model multiple dataset shared parameters complete.

previous_headings: Fitting the observed data > Multiple datasets fitted together
title: Analysis of 'Neural computation of log likelihood in control of saccadic eye movements'
text: example, multiple datasets might considered scale primary component (\(\sigma\)) vary location primary component (\(\mu\)) scale early component (\(\sigma_e\)). particular arrangement known shift. fit datasets sharing constraint, use parameters LATERmodel::fit_data function begin share_. implement shift, set share_sigma = TRUE: fitting LATER model, good practice check parameter optimisation algorithm reported issues producing parameter estimates. information contained optim_result element within value returned LATERmodel::fit_data; particular, convergence value (nonzero value indicates completion problems; see documentation optim) message value (elaborates nonzero convergence codes). look fitted parameter values, can see sigma (\(s\), just \(1 / \sigma\)) - expected request \(\sigma\) parameter shared across datasets: can visualise fits:
code: fit_shift <- LATERmodel::fit_data(   data = data,   with_early_component = TRUE,   share_sigma = TRUE,   jitter_settings = list(seed = 268918378) ) fit_shift$optim_result #> $par #>  [1] 3.51722099 3.84594345 4.50825807 4.86023422 5.03184333 5.26985858 #>  [7] 5.41248626 0.02299348 0.70937105 0.76752942 0.94380353 1.13359309 #> [13] 1.36615244 1.45198409 1.63118393 #>  #> $value #> [1] 36805.59 #>  #> $counts #> function gradient  #>     2988       NA  #>  #> $convergence #> [1] 0 #>  #> $message #> NULL fit_shift$named_fit_params LATERmodel::reciprobit_plot(   plot_data = data,   fit_params = fit_shift$named_fit_params )

previous_headings: Fitting the observed data > Multiple datasets fitted together
title: Analysis of 'Neural computation of log likelihood in control of saccadic eye movements'
text: can also consider sharing arrangements. particularly useful arrangement known swivel, occurs multiple datasets share intercept parameter (\(k\)) model. described previous explanation model parameters (fitting single dataset), intercept captures point z-score space response time latency approaches infinity. sharing intercept, multiple datasets flexibility rotate ‘swivel’ around intercept point. able share intercept, need tell LATERmodel::fit_data like \(\) parameter model refer \(k\) rather \(\mu\). setting intercept_form parameter LATERmodel::fit_data TRUE. also indicate like parameter shared setting share_a parameter LATERmodel::fit_data TRUE. Note used seed random jitter fit ‘shift’ model - ensures models compared starting points. , can check optimisation convergence: can inspect fitted parameters: can also plot fits. Note fits constrained meet common point vertical axis extrapolated infinite latency - consequence sharing intercept parameter model.
code: fit_swivel <- LATERmodel::fit_data(   data = data,   with_early_component = TRUE,   intercept_form = TRUE,   share_a = TRUE,   jitter_settings = list(seed = 268918378) ) fit_swivel$optim_result #> $par #>  [1]  4.987547312 -0.354059638 -0.236673914 -0.113631820 -0.048725096 #>  [6]  0.001541761  0.065959877  0.085843675  1.142589939  0.267662117 #> [11]  1.211808863  1.330376281  1.366441790  1.371005898  1.565925869 #>  #> $value #> [1] 36629.11 #>  #> $counts #> function gradient  #>     3328       NA  #>  #> $convergence #> [1] 0 #>  #> $message #> NULL fit_swivel$named_fit_params LATERmodel::reciprobit_plot(   plot_data = data,   fit_params = fit_swivel$named_fit_params )

previous_headings: Fitting the observed data > Multiple datasets fitted together
title: Analysis of 'Neural computation of log likelihood in control of saccadic eye movements'
text: seen can implement different sharing arrangements fitting multiple datasets. quantify compare well different sharing arrangements fit data, can use LATERmodel::compare_fits function. function accepts named list variables returned LATERmodel::fit_data, first construct variable using fits ‘shift’ ‘swivel’: pass variable argument fits parameter LATERmodel::compare_fits function: output function contains row provided fit results, ordered first row contains ‘best’ (‘preferred’) fit. assessment fit ‘best’ based relative Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) values fits, lower AIC values interpreted indicating superior fit comparison higher AIC values. aic column table reports AIC values, preferred_rel_fit_delta_aic reports difference AIC values preferred fit AIC value fit relevant row. example, ‘swivel’ fit preferred fit (also indicated preferred column) ‘swivel’ fit AIC lower AIC ‘shift’ fit. Finally, comparison also reported ‘evidence ratio’ preferred_rel_fit_evidence_ratio column. described Motulsky Christopoulos (2004), evidence ratio “tells relative likelihood, given experimental design, two models correct” (p. 147). , evidence ratio reported ‘shift’ row overwhelmingly high, indicates preferred fit (‘swivel’) much likely ‘correct’ fit ‘shift’ (noting evidence ratio calculated ratio preferred fit fit reported row).
code: fits <- list(shift = fit_shift, swivel = fit_swivel) LATERmodel::compare_fits(fits = fits)

title: Analysis of 'Neural computation of log likelihood in control of saccadic eye movements'
text: walkthrough, seen can use package conduct analysis response time data using LATER model. First, represented raw data data table columns name, condition, time rows corresponding single trials. used LATERmodel::prepare_data function convert raw data format suitable subsequent analysis. used LATERmodel::fit_data function fit parameters LATER model data; either single dataset, multiple datasets considered separately, multiple datasets sharing LATER model parameters. saw use LATERmodel::reciprobit_plot visualise observed data model fits ‘reciprobit’ space used LATER model. Finally, used LATERmodel::compare_fits function compare goodness--fit multiple fits data.

previous_headings: Loading in Data, and Creating a Named Dataset From These Data
title: Use LATERmodel through R Shiny app
text: Reaction time data can loaded clicking “Browse…” button “Upload cvs file” left sidebar navigating file wish upload local computer. Data needs comma-separated values (.csv) file. following random sample 10 rows taken sample data file carpenter_williams_1995 (provided LATERmodel package), demonstrates format: data file, participant gives unique identifier participant tested, condition gives label particular experiment performed participant, time gives reaction time milliseconds. example, carpenter_williams_1995, two participants labelled “” “b”, performed seven experiments probability target appearing particular side changed (labelled “p05”, “p10”, “p25”, “p50”, “p75”, “p90” “p95” complete file). Data files can also include optional column labelled “color”, determine colour plot. Colours can listed names accepted R (e.g. “darkgray”) can hexadecimal colour codes. can see complete list color names accepted R using built-colors function (show first 20):
code: dplyr::sample_n(LATERmodel::carpenter_williams_1995, 10) #>    participant condition time #> 1            a       p95  240 #> 2            b       p90  150 #> 3            a       p10  210 #> 4            a       p90  150 #> 5            b       p95  130 #> 6            a       p90  180 #> 7            a       p95  170 #> 8            a       p90  180 #> 9            b       p90  220 #> 10           a       p90  210 head(colors(), 20) #>  [1] "white"         "aliceblue"     "antiquewhite"  "antiquewhite1" #>  [5] "antiquewhite2" "antiquewhite3" "antiquewhite4" "aquamarine"    #>  [9] "aquamarine1"   "aquamarine2"   "aquamarine3"   "aquamarine4"   #> [13] "azure"         "azure1"        "azure2"        "azure3"        #> [17] "azure4"        "beige"         "bisque"        "bisque1"

previous_headings: Loading in Data, and Creating a Named Dataset From These Data
what: Creating a Named Dataset From These Data
title: Use LATERmodel through R Shiny app
text: loaded, Dataset can created, subsets loaded data can fitted plotted. create Dataset: Click Participant drop-menu select participant wish include. Note one participant can selected time. Click Conditions drop menu select condition included Dataset. multiple conditions selected succession, merged single named Dataset. Give Dataset unique name Dataset Name field. Click Add dataset. new Dataset appended table “Created datasets” right screen, raw data plotted figure. Datasets can removed clicking “Remove” button corresponding row table.

what: Fitting the LATER Model to a Dataset
title: Use LATERmodel through R Shiny app
text: “Fit model” tab, click “Datasets fit” field, successively select Dataset(s) wish fit. several fitting options available: Use intercept form: select option wish constrain fits common intercept (\(k\)) infinite time reciprobit plot (common interpretation “swivel”). Note intercept \(k\) equal \(\frac{\mu}{\sigma}\). Fit early component: select option wish fit include parameter \(\sigma_{e}\) quantifies tail early responses reaction times. Fitting criterion allows select whether like perform maximum likelihood fit (recommended) fit minimises Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) statistic. fitting multiple Datasets using shared parameters, Use minmax option optimise fit worse fitted dataset collection Datasets. Shared parameters: options determine parameters, , common value Datasets fit. Note , selected multiple Datasets, must least one shared parameter fit proceed. suitable options selected, provide unique name fit Fit Name field, perform fit clicking Fit datasets button. Upon fitting, fit parameters appended table fits right screen, along fitting criterion (“ks” “likelihood”), value fit criterion, fit’s negative log-likelihood (natural log), Akaike Information Criterion (“aic”). Fits also visualised plot, drop-menu select fit like visualise. Example fits : Swivel infinite time: select Use intercept form \(k = \frac{\mu}{\sigma}\)” list shared parameters. Fit early component (, selected, option share \(\sigma_{e}\)) optional. Shift: fit \(\mu\) differs Datasets, \(\sigma\) common: leave Use intercept form unchecked, Shared parameters select \(\sigma\). , options early components optional. Swivel cumulative probability 50%: corresponding alteration \(\sigma\) alone datasets. Leave Use intercept form unchecked, Shared parameters select \(\mu\). , options early components optional.

title: Use LATERmodel through R Shiny app
text: Download results tab, use Name fit drop-menu select fit wish visualise customise. Options include: Time unit: latencies expressed milliseconds, deciseconds, seconds. Label x-axis: x-axis can labelled either “Latency” “Reaction time”. Time range (ms): range values x axis, milliseconds, visualised. Probability range: range values y axis visualised. Reciprobit axes: default, figures plotted Promptness x-axis, Z-score y-axis. Selecting option also include latency cumulative percent probability secondary axis ticks labels, used traditional reciprobit plots. Plot dimensions (width, height, units): dimensions plot, units dimensions . Figure format: format wish download figure . happy figure customisation, (along data fits used generate figure) can downloaded clicking Download button.

title: Use LATERmodel through R Shiny app
text: like continue work another time different computer, share work someone else like replicate analysis, can save progress using button Save state app. download file .rds extension, need upload shiny app ready continue analysis work.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Maria del Mar Quiroga. Author, maintainer. Damien Mannion. Author. Edoardo Tescari. Author. Andrew Anderson. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Quiroga M, Mannion D, Tescari E, Anderson (2024). LATERmodel: Linear Approach Threshold Ergodic Rate Reaction Times. R package version 0.1.0, https://unimelbmdap.github.io/LATERmodel/, https://github.com/unimelbmdap/LATERmodel.
code: @Manual{,   title = {LATERmodel: Linear Approach to Threshold with Ergodic Rate for Reaction Times},   author = {Maria del Mar Quiroga and Damien Mannion and Edoardo Tescari and Andrew Anderson},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.1.0, https://unimelbmdap.github.io/LATERmodel/},   url = {https://github.com/unimelbmdap/LATERmodel}, }

what: Linear Approach to Threshold with Ergodic Rate for Reaction Times
title: Linear Approach to Threshold with Ergodic Rate for Reaction Times
text: LATERmodel R package open-source implementation Roger Carpenter’s Linear Approach Threshold Ergodic Rate (LATER) model (R. Carpenter (1981), Noorani Carpenter (2016)). package enables easy visualisation reaction time data LATER’s signature reciprobit space, well estimating parameters fit model datasets, comparing raw datasets, comparing fits (.e., dataset better explained shift swivel?), adding early component, etc. package also includes two canonical datasets digitised R. H. S. Carpenter Williams (1995) Reddi, Asrress, Carpenter (2003).

title: Linear Approach to Threshold with Ergodic Rate for Reaction Times
text: can install development version LATERmodel GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("unimelbmdap/LATERmodel")

title: Linear Approach to Threshold with Ergodic Rate for Reaction Times
text: Load digitised data Figure 1 Carpenter Williams (1995): Extract data corresponding participant (Figure 1.): data analysis functions within package require raw data first undergo pre-processing using prepare_data function. pass raw_data variable argument raw_data parameter prepare_data perform pre-processing: Fit condition individually (shared parameters ), include early component : Visualise raw data best individual fits:
code: library(LATERmodel)  data(carpenter_williams_1995) raw_data <- subset(carpenter_williams_1995, participant == "a") data <- prepare_data(raw_data = raw_data) data_fit <- individual_later_fit(data, with_early_component = TRUE) reciprobit_plot(data, data_fit)

text: Carpenter, R. H., & Williams, M. L. L. (1995). Neural computation log likelihood control saccadic eye movements. Nature, 377(6544), 59-62.

what: Compares the goodness-of-fit of a set of fit outcomes. — compare_fits
title: Compares the goodness-of-fit of a set of fit outcomes. — compare_fits
text: Compares goodness--fit set fit outcomes.

title: Compares the goodness-of-fit of a set of fit outcomes. — compare_fits
code: compare_fits(fits)

title: Compares the goodness-of-fit of a set of fit outcomes. — compare_fits
text: fits list item name identifies fit value given output LATERmodel::fit_data.

title: Compares the goodness-of-fit of a set of fit outcomes. — compare_fits
text: list fit comparison results, ordered fit lowest AIC value first row. aic contains fit AIC values. preferred_rel_fit_delta_aic AIC value fit relative AIC fit lowest AIC (preferred AIC - current AIC). preferred_rel_fit_evidence_ratio evidence ratio fit lowest AIC relative current fit. preferred boolean indicates whether fit lowest AIC value among fits ('preferred').

title: Compares the goodness-of-fit of a set of fit outcomes. — compare_fits
text: 'evidence ratio' calculated per Motulsky & Christopolous (2004), p. 146.

title: Compares the goodness-of-fit of a set of fit outcomes. — compare_fits
code: data <- dplyr::filter(   carpenter_williams_1995, participant == "a",   condition == "p05" | condition == "p95" ) data <- prepare_data(data) fit_a <- fit_data(data = data, share_a = TRUE) fit_b <- fit_data(data = data, share_sigma = TRUE) comparison <- compare_fits(fits = list(a = fit_a, b = fit_b))

what: Fit a LATER model to a single dataset or a pair of datasets. — fit_data
title: Fit a LATER model to a single dataset or a pair of datasets. — fit_data
text: Fit LATER model single dataset pair datasets.

title: Fit a LATER model to a single dataset or a pair of datasets. — fit_data
code: fit_data(   data,   share_a = FALSE,   share_sigma = FALSE,   share_sigma_e = FALSE,   with_early_component = FALSE,   intercept_form = FALSE,   use_minmax = FALSE,   fit_criterion = "likelihood",   jitter_settings = list(n = 7, prop = 0.5, seed = NA) )

title: Fit a LATER model to a single dataset or a pair of datasets. — fit_data
text: data data frame columns name promptness. share_a, share_sigma, share_sigma_e FALSE (default), dataset parameter. TRUE, datasets share relevant parameter. with_early_component TRUE, model contains second 'early' component absent FALSE (default). intercept_form FALSE (default), parameter describes mu parameter model; TRUE, parameter describes k parameter model (intercept). use_minmax FALSE (default), optimiser targets sum goodness--fit values across datasets; TRUE, instead targets maximum goodness--fit values across datasets. fit_criterion String indicating criterion used optimise fit seeking minimum. ks: Kolmogorov-Smirnov statistic. likelihood: Negative log-likelihood. jitter_settings Settings running fitting multiple times randomly-generated offsets ('jitter') applied starting estimates. n: many jitter iterations run (default 7); total number fits n + 1 (un-jittered start points also fit). prop: maximum jitter offset, proportion start value (default 0.5). seed: Seed random jitter generator (default unseeded).

title: Fit a LATER model to a single dataset or a pair of datasets. — fit_data
text: list fitting arguments outcomes. fitted_params named list fitted parameter values. named_fit_params data frame rows given dataset names columns given parameter names. loglike overall log-likelihood fit. aic "Akaike's 'Information Criterion'" value model. optim_result raw output stats::optim best fit. jitter_optim_results contains raw output call stats::optim different start points.

title: Fit a LATER model to a single dataset or a pair of datasets. — fit_data
code: data <- data.frame(name = "test", promptness = rnorm(100, 3, 1)) fit <- fit_data(data = data) data_other <- data.frame(name = "test_2", promptness = rnorm(100, 1, 1)) fit_shared_sigma <- fit_data(   data = rbind(data, data_other), share_sigma = TRUE )

what: Fit individual LATER model to each dataset in a dataframe of datasets — individual_later_fit
title: Fit individual LATER model to each dataset in a dataframe of datasets — individual_later_fit
text: Fit individual LATER model dataset dataframe datasets

title: Fit individual LATER model to each dataset in a dataframe of datasets — individual_later_fit
code: individual_later_fit(   df,   with_early_component = FALSE,   fit_criterion = "likelihood",   jitter_settings = list(n = 7, prop = 0.5, seed = NA) )

title: Fit individual LATER model to each dataset in a dataframe of datasets — individual_later_fit
text: df dataframe columns: time, name, promptness, e_cdf with_early_component TRUE, model contains second 'early' component absent FALSE (default). fit_criterion String indicating criterion used optimise fit seeking minimum. ks: Kolmogorov-Smirnov statistic. neg_loglike: Negative log-likelihood. jitter_settings Settings running fitting multiple times randomly-generated offsets ('jitter') applied starting estimates. n: many jitter iterations run (default 7). prop: maximum jitter offset, proportion start value (default 0.5). seed: Seed random jitter generator (default unseeded).

title: Fit individual LATER model to each dataset in a dataframe of datasets — individual_later_fit
text: dataframe one row named dataset df columns equal LATER model parameters returned fit_data$named_fit_params

title: Fit individual LATER model to each dataset in a dataframe of datasets — individual_later_fit
code: a <- dplyr::filter(carpenter_williams_1995, participant == "a") df <- prepare_data(a) fit_params <- individual_later_fit(df)

what: Apply two-sample KS test to all pairs of datasets contained within a dataframe — ks_compare

text: Apply two-sample KS test pairs datasets contained within dataframe

code: ks_compare(df, correct_multiple_comparisons = TRUE)

title: Apply two-sample KS test to all pairs of datasets contained within a dataframe — ks_compare
text: df dataframe datasets columns: name time, one unique name per dataset correct_multiple_comparisons TRUE, adjustment made p-values based Holm, 1979, simple sequentially rejective multiple test procedure

title: Apply two-sample KS test to all pairs of datasets contained within a dataframe — ks_compare
text: dataframe columns name1, name2, D, p_value

title: Apply two-sample KS test to all pairs of datasets contained within a dataframe — ks_compare
code: data <- prepare_data(dplyr::filter(   carpenter_williams_1995,   participant == "b" )) ks_compare(data) #> Warning: p-value will be approximate in the presence of ties #> Warning: p-value will what: Prepares data for reciprobit plot — prepare_data
title: Prepares data for reciprobit plot — prepare_data
text: Prepares data reciprobit plot

title: Prepares data for reciprobit plot — prepare_data
code: prepare_data(raw_data, time_unit = "ms", name_separator = "_")

title: Prepares data for reciprobit plot — prepare_data
text: raw_data Vector reaction times single participant, dataframe containing column called time reaction times optional columns: column called name unique label dataset column called participant unique id per participant another called condition unique label condition. case name dataset constructed participant+name_separator+condition. column called color contains one hexadecimal color code dataset. case name dataset set name color. time_unit Units reaction times rt_vector, must one "ms", "ds", "s". name_separator raw_data dataframe contain name column, participant condition columns, name dataset constructed participant+name_separator+condition.

title: Prepares data for reciprobit plot — prepare_data
text: dataframe columns: time, color, name, promptness, e_cdf.

title: Prepares data for reciprobit plot — prepare_data
code: df <- prepare_data(carpenter_williams_1995)

what: Compute the empirical cumulative distribution function for promptness — promptness_ecdf
title: Compute the empirical cumulative distribution function for promptness — promptness_ecdf
text: Compute empirical cumulative distribution function promptness

title: Compute the empirical cumulative distribution function for promptness — promptness_ecdf
code: promptness_ecdf(promptness, adjust_for_times = TRUE, eval_unique = FALSE)

title: Compute the empirical cumulative distribution function for promptness — promptness_ecdf
text: promptness vector promptness values (1 / times) adjust_for_times TRUE (default), returned y value 1 - y = P(1/promptness <= 1/x). FALSE, returned yvalue thaty = P(promptness <= x)`. eval_unique FALSE (default), ECDF evaluated values promptness. TRUE, ECDF evaluated unique values promptness.

title: Compute the empirical cumulative distribution function for promptness — promptness_ecdf
text: data frame attributes: x values ECDF evaluated. y evaluated value ECDF.

title: Compute the empirical cumulative distribution function for promptness — promptness_ecdf
code: p <- promptness_ecdf(promptness = rnorm(100, 3, 1))

what: Plot reaction times and LATER model fit in reciprobit axes — reciprobit_plot
title: Plot reaction times and LATER model fit in reciprobit axes — reciprobit_plot
text: Plot reaction times LATER model fit reciprobit axes

title: Plot reaction times and LATER model fit in reciprobit axes — reciprobit_plot
code: reciprobit_plot(   plot_data,   fit_params = NULL,   time_breaks = c(0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.5, 1),   probit_breaks = c(0.1, 1, 5, 10, 20, 50, 80, 90, 95, 99, 99.9),   z_breaks = c(-2, -1, 0, 1, 2),   xrange = NULL,   yrange = NULL )

title: Plot reaction times and LATER model fit in reciprobit axes — reciprobit_plot
text: plot_data dataframe columns: time, name, promptness, e_cdf. Optionally, may color column, contains hex values, one unique hex value per named dataset fit_params dataframe one row named dataset columns equal LATER model parameters returned fit_data$named_fit_params time_breaks Desired tick marks x axis, expressed promptness (1/s) probit_breaks Desired tick marks y axis probit space z_breaks Desired tick marks secondary y axis, z values xrange Desired range x axis, promptness (1/s) yrange Desired range y axis, cumulative probability space

title: Plot reaction times and LATER model fit in reciprobit axes — reciprobit_plot
text: reciprobit plot cumulative probability distribution reaction times

title: Plot reaction times and LATER model fit in reciprobit axes — reciprobit_plot
code: a <- dplyr::filter(   carpenter_williams_1995, participant == "a",   condition == "p95" | condition == "p05" ) df <- prepare_data(a) fit_params <- individual_later_fit(df, with_early_component = TRUE) reciprobit_plot(df, fit_params)

what: Simulate a dataset given model parameters. — simulate_dataset
title: Simulate a dataset given model parameters. — simulate_dataset
text: Generates samples set provided LATER model parameters, option iteratively replace invalid samples (reaction times <= 0).

title: Simulate a dataset given model parameters. — simulate_dataset
code: simulate_dataset(   n,   later_mu,   later_sd,   early_sd = NULL,   seed = NA,   allow_negative_times = FALSE )

title: Simulate a dataset given model parameters. — simulate_dataset
text: n Number samples (trials) later_mu Mean later component. later_sd Standard deviation later component. early_sd Standard deviation early component, NULL early component (default). seed Seed random number generator allow_negative_times FALSE (default), random samples negative response times iteratively replaced returned samples positive. TRUE, replacement performed.

title: Simulate a dataset given model parameters. — simulate_dataset
text: Vector response times (seconds)

title: Simulate a dataset given model parameters. — simulate_dataset
LATERmodel 0.2.0
text: Changed approach determine start values sigma sigma_e parameters, using skewness observed promptness distribution weight relationship parameters empirical standard deviation. Added option perform fitting repeatedly random offsets (jitters) start points (default), returning best repeated fits. Updated article analysis Carpenter & Williams data include details jittering.

title: LATERmodel 0.1.0
text: Initial version
